pe_description: The Food & Staples Retailing sub-sector in Indonesia has a P/E ratio of 7.69, which is lower than the average IDX P/E ratio. This sub-sector outperformed its last year's P/E ratio and ranked 11th among other sub-sectors in the Indonesian market. Three companies, '###Multipolar Tbk####', '###Millennium Pharmacon International Tbk####', and '###PT Kurniamitra Duta Sentosa Tbk.####', have the most undervalued P/E ratios, while '###PT Segar Kumala Indonesia Tbk####' is overvalued and should be avoided. Factors that could influence growth within this sub-sector include consumer spending, food prices, and competition.
health_description: The Food & Staples Retailing sub-sector in Indonesia, comprising 14 companies, has experienced a decline in average price changes compared to the IDX in the last 30 days, ranking 25th among sub-sectors. With no new listings in the current month, the last new listing occurred on 2022-08-09, indicating potential barriers to entry. Out of the 14 companies, only 4 exhibited positive price changes. Factors that may influence the market health index of this sub-sector include changes in consumer spending patterns, competition, government regulations, and supply chain disruptions. The Indonesian government body responsible for regulating the Food & Staples Retailing sub-sector is the Ministry of Trade, whose policies and decisions can impact the resilience of this sub-sector in the country.
growth_description: The Food & Staples Retailing sub-sector in Indonesia has experienced a moderate growth in the past year, with an average YoY quarter earnings change of 4.87% and an average YoY quarter revenue change of 8.69%. This sub-sector ranks 21st in terms of earnings growth and 19th in terms of revenue growth compared to other sub-sectors. Within this sub-sector, ###Multipolar Tbk####, ###PT Segar Kumala Indonesia Tbk####, and ###PT Kurniamitra Duta Sentosa Tbk.#### stand out as the companies with the highest YoY earning growth, YoY revenue growth, and net profit margin, respectively. However, the growth of this sub-sector can be affected by various factors, including changes in consumer spending patterns, competition from online retailers, and government regulations specifically impacting the food and staples retailing industry in Indonesia.
